summary: Self-emptying robot vacuum with obstacle avoidance smart enough to dodge pet accidents, shoes, and cords.
editorsNote: Reddit's r/roomba frequently complains about iRobot's app being buggy and slow to load, and the Clean Base being surprisingly loud during the 30-second emptying cycle. content:
How to never vacuum your floors again (seriously)

Vacuuming is one of those chores that expands to fill whatever time you give it. Quick pass through the living room? That's 15 minutes. The whole house? An hour plus. With pets, you're vacuuming every 2-3 days or living with tumbleweeds of fur. With kids, there's a constant layer of crumbs. Most people spend 4-6 hours per month pushing a vacuum around â€” time that's pure maintenance with zero upside. You never think "wow, that was a great vacuuming session." You just dread the next one.

The iRobot Roomba j9+ is a self-emptying robot vacuum with AI-powered obstacle avoidance that handles floors autonomously. The P.O.O.P. (Pet Owner Official Promise) guarantee means if it runs over pet waste, iRobot replaces it free â€” but the avoidance is good enough that it rarely happens. It identifies and dodges shoes, cords, socks, pet bowls, and other floor clutter using front-facing cameras and machine learning. Unlike cheaper robot vacuums that bump into everything and get stuck, the j9+ navigates deliberately around obstacles. The self-emptying Clean Base holds up to 60 days of debris, so you genuinely forget about vacuuming for two months at a time.

The features that make this a "set and forget" device are smart mapping (it learns your floor plan and lets you send it to specific rooms by name), automatic carpet detection (increases suction when it transitions from hardwood to carpet), and dirt detection (focuses extra passes on high-traffic areas). Scheduling is intelligent â€” it suggests cleaning times based on your routine, pollen season, and pet shedding patterns. It integrates with Alexa, Google Home, and Home Assistant for voice commands and broader smart home automations like "vacuum when everyone leaves the house."

The real-world impact is 4-6 hours per month of vacuuming eliminated entirely. At ~$800, it's not cheap, but consider the math: if your time is worth $30/hour (conservatively), the Roomba saves you $120-180/month in time value. It pays for itself in 5-6 months. Beyond time, there's the mental load â€” removing "I need to vacuum" from your perpetual to-do list is surprisingly freeing. Pet owners report the biggest quality-of-life improvement: floors stay clean between runs, and guests stop commenting on pet hair. Compared to the Roborock S8 MaxV Ultra (which adds mopping), the j9+ is the better choice if you only need vacuuming and want iRobot's superior obstacle avoidance.

âš¡ Set it up in 5 minutes

  1. Place the Clean Base against a wall with 1.5 feet of clearance on each side and plug it in
  2. Remove the Roomba from packaging, place it on the Clean Base to charge
  3. Download the iRobot Home app and follow the pairing wizard
  4. Let it run a mapping pass of your home (takes 1-2 hours, does not clean during first map)
  5. Set your weekly schedule and room preferences â€” then forget about vacuuming
frictionNote: Expensive at ~$800. The Clean Base is large and needs a wall outlet with clearance. Maps take 2-3 runs to fully learn your space.
